case_vignette:
A sexually active 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of itching in the area of his genitals. He also reports burning on micturition. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with oral metformin. Pelvic examination shows tender, atrophic white papules on the glans and prepuce, with erythema of the surrounding skin. The urinary meatus is narrowed and sclerotic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? 
A) Perform a biopsy of the glans
B) Perform a biopsy of the prepuce
C) D) Perform a biopsy of the glans and prepuce
D) Perform a biopsy of the glans and prepuce, and also of the urinary meatus
E) Perform a biopsy of the urinary meatus
Answer: D) Perform a biopsy of the glans and prepuce, and also of the urinary meatus
The correct answer is D) Perform a biopsy of the glans and prepuce, and also of the urinary meatus. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with lichen sclerosus, a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the genital area. Lichen sclerosus is more common in women, but it can also occur in men. The condition is characterized by white, atrophic papules and erythema of the affected skin, as well as narrowing and sclerosis of the urinary meatus. A biopsy of the affected skin and urinary meatus is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. 
Note: The question and answer choices are written in a way that is neutral with respect to gender, but the correct answer is based on the fact that lichen sclerosus is more common in women.
